text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal?

text: Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: -and then start the new thing. Family Member: Oh I didn’t realize that. Doctor: Otherwise you can get drug interaction- Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal. Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there.

text: Family Member: He had egg McMuffins today, too. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I had an egg McMuffin, but you know what? I ate it without a muffin. Doctor: Yes and no, but you shouldn’t - you should have some stability in your sugar. You know what I mean? Patient: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Doctor: Three eighty five, no matter where you are in your day, is too high. Patient: Yes. Yeah. Family Member: It will make you feel sick. Doctor: It’ll make you feel sick. Family Member: And tired.

text: Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –

text: Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term. Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay?

But you said from the beginning you don’t want it to go over six hundred. Family Member 1: No one said that.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
